awd_titl_txt: Loop Quantum Gravity with Cosmological Constant
awd_abstract_narration:
Einstein's General Relativity (GR) is the theory describing the physics of the classical gravitational field. The theory of GR has made tremendous progress in understanding the fundamental aspects of space and time and has been successful in making predictions for the evolution of the universe and various astrophysical phenomena. However it is well-known that the theory of GR is incomplete. It loses its capability of making predictions in extremely strong gravitational fields, e.g. inside a black hole or at the very early stage of the universe near the big bang. One of the most fundamental open questions in physics is how to complete GR in order to predict physics in an extremely strong gravitational field. The complete theory of gravity that we are searching for is called "Quantum Gravity". The theory of Quantum Gravity should play a crucial role in describing the physics inside black holes and helping us to understand the early universe near the big bang. Eventually Quantum Gravity will lead us to a revolutionary understanding of space and time. This award supports the development of a candidate Quantum Gravity theory known as "Loop Quantum Gravity" (LQG), which offers significant promise in addressing the questions posed. 

The work supported by this award focuses on developing the theory of LQG with a cosmological constant in 4 dimensions, in particular the spinfoam formulation of theory. The main objectives of this project are: (1) Investigating the continuum limit of the theory, in particular the emergence of smooth spacetime geometries and Einstein equations from the spinfoam amplitude, and relating the spinfoam formulation to the recent program of emergent gravity from quantum information, (2) analyzing the quantum effects of curvature singularities in the framework of spinfoams, and to extract physical observables, and (3) developing a canonical framework closely related to the spinfoam formulation with a cosmological constant.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
How to define a quantum theory of gravity is one of the most fundamental open questions in physics. Supported by this award, the PI focuses on the development of a candidate Quantum Gravity theory known as "Loop Quantum Gravity" (LQG). LQG is a theory featured with the background independence and non-perturbative quantization of spacetime. This project focuses on developing the theory of LQG with cosmological constant in 4 dimensions, in particular the spinfoam formulation of theory. The key outcomes from this project are: (1) An important progress are made in the semiclassical analysis of the spinfoam formulation in LQG. The curved geometries, characterizing gravitational field by General Relativity, are shown to emerge from the spinfoam amplitude in the semiclassical regime. This resolves a long-standing confusion in the LQG community, known as the flatness problem. (2) 4-dimensional Lorentzian spinfoam model with cosmological constant is developed and shown to enjoy two key features: the finiteness and semiclassical consistency. These features indicates that the model is promising in both mathematical and physical aspects. The model is ready for being applied to model-building in physical situations. (3) Several numerical computational methods are developed and take part in the recent advances in the numerical methods in LQG. These methods are crucial preparations for applying the spinfoam formulation to various physical situations, such as black holes and cosmology. (4) LQG is related to quantum computation. A linear-optical quantum simulator is designed to make the optical quantum gates simulate the spinfoam amplitudes of LQG. The spinfoam amplitudes can be efficiently computable with the linear-optical quantum computer, which can be implemented using current technologies.

The outcomes of broader impact includes designing a series of quantum field theory courses in FAU’s graduate curriculum, and mentoring PhD students’ research. One of the PI's PhD students is successfully awarded with her PhD and obtained a postdoc position in prestigious research institution.
